title: Probing the Solid-Electrolyte Interface in Lithium Ion Batteries with Time-of-Flight Secondary Ion Mass Spectrometry
content: The performance of lithium-ion batteries is partially determined by their solid-electrolyte interface (SEI). The distribution and chemical speciation of lithium and the interaction of lithium with other electrolyte components is critical information in the search non-flammable solid-state electrolytes for more efficient lithium ion batteries [1]. Obtaining such information from X-ray and electron microscopies is limited by their low sensitivity to lithium and hydrogen. However, imaging and depth profiling by time-of-flight secondary ion mass spectrometry (ToF-SIMS) can reveal three dimensional atomic and molecular distributions in the SEI at micrometer resolutions that are independent of elemental mass [2, 3]. Model battery samples were prepared with a solid electrolyte composed of a conducting polymer, a lithium salt, and ceramic nanofibers [4]. Voxels of the SEI in these samples were probed by ToF-SIMS using 30 keV Bi3+primary ions from a liquid metal ion gun (IONTOF M6, MÃ¼nster, Germany) with simultaneous depth profiling with an argon gas cluster ion beam. ToF-SIMS data analysis strategies for this and other solid electrolyte formulations will be discussed that select secondary ions most representative of different SEI components before and after electrochemical cycling; address variation in ion yields with species, lateral position, or depth; avoid detector saturation; and reduce deleterious sample charging effects.
